pros: I like working at Amazon because it gives me a stable job while learning very beneficial skills to help build my career. The flexibility to find another job within the company and move internally is something that should not be undervalued. The quality of people I have met working at Amazon doesn't compare to my previous employment experiences. Most people who work at Amazon have something they are striving for and are taking advantage of the many career building resources offered by Amazon. I look at it as you are who you surround yourself with and I like being surrounded by the people I am surrounded by at work.
cons: Some of the jobs may have schedules you don't like all that much, especially entry level positions but if you always have the ability to look for another job and move to a position that has a schedule more to your preference. I ended up doing this after a year and a half.

review_title: 3.5 stars actually due to mediocre salary and attitude towards any kind of bonus
pros:
+ nice and safe working environment
+ fruits/veg day twice a week
+ Language trainings
+ access to LinkedIn Learning platform
+ coffe/tea/etc
cons:
- the overall work experience at Amazon deeply depends on the project/task you are assigned to and it also depends on the manager you are working with. 

- The salary grew to become a very big problem in Amazon. There are people with 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 or 7 years of experience that are „rewarded” with the same or less amount of money that a new joiner gets now in 2022. This practice is covered in the ”we do not reward tenure, we reward performance” policy. This is EXTREMELY demotivating.

- the team buildings became lamer and lamer with every year that flew by

- No Easter bonus. Christmas bonus is a matter of luck I guess, we never know if we get it or not. This year we got it. 

- besides Linkedin Learning, there are very few meaningful and helpful training that can help you really grow as a person and in your career.

pros: Some of the best reasons

review_title: Can be good, but often bad
pros:
- Lots of valuable knowledge gained while coming up the steep knowledge curve
- Compensation is good even though it less than other FAANG companies
- Depending on your team you can work on engaging problems that grow your career
cons:
- SDEs are meat in the sausage grinder of producing an endless stream of often poorly conceived features
- Oncall can be brutal where you're getting multiple Sev 2's in a night and need to stay up all night and then work the following day
- Not a collaborative culture. Everyone seems to just want to survive and do their own thing. I've been here for two years and basically every project has had me as an island
- Away team work where you work on another team's service is painful where you need to deep dive on their stack and effect changes the owning team often doesn't want
- Hard pass on Amazon if you've got a competing tech offer

pros:
Some pros are...
- Getting the experience of working at AWS and personal growth.
- you will be challenged to get out of your comfort zone to deliver results which will develop you professionally 
- a lot of smart and capable colleagues 
- work on some cool projects and support some innovative teams
- if you can make it here you can be successful anywhere
- will open up more opportunities you ever thought possible
cons:
Some cons are...
- Hard to have control of your own schedule/work-life can sometimes be tough
- Very demanding schedule and very little time to think Big picture
- Very ambiguous environment and self service org. 
- Although training is provided you still would need to ask questions and seek answers aggressively to resolve many issues you come across in a timely manner.

job_title: User Experience Designer in Seattle, WA
pros: Almost all teams are growing quickly and looking for new ideas - if you want to supercharge your career by taking on big initiatives and coming up with new ideas to push through, this is a great company.
cons:
Promotion process is a very long and difficult process, and the individual looking to be promoted has to manage 90% of the work. You have to demonstrate you're operating at the level you're looking to be promoted to for at least 6 months, write a document with all of your evidence, and then wait for a quarter-long process - often to find out at the end you're missing a certain set of evidence so you have to wait another quarter to re-apply.
This process by nature rewards employees who are confident in their abilities, and quick to voice why they should be promoted. This process hurts employees who are heads down on their work, soft-spoken, or not as confident in their abilities (regardless of what their abilities actually are).

Pay is also quickly becoming very non-competitive against other companies.

job_title: Software Development Engineer in Vancouver, BC
pros:
I left a company plagued with slow and bureaucratic processes (e.g. takes 6+ months to launch a very simple CRUD API), managers who were not very technologically inclined, incompetent and/or unmotivated team members, and an organization focused on short-term gains and 'quick-wins'. In contrast, I have found Amazon (AWS org) to be more oriented to long-term thinking and actively fighting against complacency.

- Very talented and intelligent team members
- Super structured onboarding process 
- Great internal tools + education resources
- Lots of transparency + structure on career development/promotion process
- Team members are motivated to help you get you up to speed 
- Team members are clear and concise communicators and know how to best leverage messaging like Slack (minimize use of email and unnecessary meetings)
cons:
I was initially hesitant to join AWS due to the narrative produced on various online communities, but I have found most of those to be generalizations and not necessarily indicative of cultures on individual teams. In other words, your experience will vary based on team + manager.

- Vision Benefits could be improved
- Would be great to have WealthSimple as a provider option for stock plan / RRSP
- Stipend for office supplies would be preferred over a commuting stipend
- Would have been great to get some swag in the onboarding package

job_title: Senior Client Lead Recruiter in Dallas, TX
pros: The pay is great! I'm making more money than I ever have after 25 years of recruiting.
cons: Most of Amazon does not follow the full cycle recruiting model so it can be challenging to establish rapport with candidates and hiring managers. The Client Lead Recruiter is also known as a Closer and their role is to extend offers, onboard and serve as the face of recruiting to hiring managers. Also, there's limited control of your daily work schedule as the Recruiting Coordinator schedules interview debriefs on your calendar and Recruiters are required to attend all debriefs for their client group. Priority in scheduling will be given to the hiring manager and interview panel versus Recruiting. Since appointments can be rescheduled or cancelled, it's really difficult to try and plan your work day as a result. The volume of requisitions can be intimidating. Currently, I manage 160 reqs. Although there's a Sourcer on the front end of the process, that's still 80 reqs that I'm overseeing if you cut the count in half.

cons:
- Frugality is put into practice. For a large organization there is very little budget for social events/team building etc.

*Great pay
cons:
*You must be self motivated, and self directed

*Scheduling meetings with other managers can be challenging.
*PTO accrual for a first year employee is low.

job_title: Business Development in San Jose, CA
pros: Amazon integrates the LPs into everything they do. Into writing business strategy, decision making, and personal development. It's not just posted on a wall. cons: Amazon is a massive company and although they keep the teams smaller, it takes some time to get the "lay of the land". Sometimes their own process and procedures get in the way. One key principle is a bias for action, but not everyone or every organization does this well.

review_title: AWS - Great Employer for Digital Construction Professionals
pros:
Great working environment. Work From Home/Office policy is flexible and most people are satisfied with their arrangements to date. This might change in the future but I'm very happy with it the moment.

I felt very welcomed to the team and had a brilliant on-boarding buddy and manager. They helped me get into a position were I could start assisting the team in a very short time. 

Fantastic induction\embark period to help adjust to the Amazonian way. It opens your eyes to how big Amazon is as an employer and because of that what the possible opportunities are their for you to progress your career.
cons:
At the moment, highlighting cons is hard...
The one that might be considered a con would be the working across regions. Due to timezone differences it can be hard to arrange times that suit, but with a little planning and understanding from both sides it is regulated to a very mild nuisance.

BUT at the same time you get to hear diverse opinions from across the globe and hear how other people and approach similar issues.

review_title: Tons of experience and opportunity, but very dependent on a good manager
pros: You learn so much in a short amount of time at Amazon, and the longer you stay and the more orgs you work in, the more you learn. If you are self-driven and motivated enough, you can spend a lifetime working here and still learn something new every day.
cons: Upward growth is very dependent on office politics and your manager. In a span of 7 years, I worked in three orgs, had four roles, and more than ten managers (all male) because my managers turned over so much. Every time I got a new manager, it felt like I was starting over in the position. None of my managers were future focused or even resembled mentors. I had to look elsewhere in the company for that.

pros:
Work for the largest cloud computing company 
Work with some of the smartest people on earth
Great culture based around employee well-being
Supportive and helpful team based environment
Fantastic company values and LP's
cons:
Big beast to get your head around
Complicated structure
Intricate internal systems

pros: Schedule flexibility, weekly pay, college tuition benefit, 4-day work week
cons: Repetitive, boring, dull environment, no music allowed, short breaks

pros: Pay is decent I guess
cons:
You are forced to work as fast as possible. This means scanning products and putting them on shelves/taking them off shelves as quickly as possible. The work is mind-numbing and going at the pace you do, you will eventually make a mistake. When that happens, a manager will hunt you down wherever you are and reprimand you. 

They keep track of all these mistakes. If you happen to be one of the many, many seasonal workers and hope to join Amazon proper, you better make sure you don't screw up. Because if you make more than a couple mistakes, they won't let you.

They also have this fun little rule (at least at the warehouse I worked at) where employees can only bring in clear bottles of water and you aren't allowed to have them on you while you work. So if you get thirsty, you better run to the water fountain fast. Meanwhile, the managers sitting around get to flaunt this rule entirely.

I've rated the "diversity and inclusion" section a 5 star because, at least at the grunt level, Amazon doesn't seem to be discriminatory in the slightest. But when you're all treated like cogs in a machine, personal background hardly matters.

review_title: Definitely would not recommend to family or friends
job_title: L3 Process Assistant Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
The hiring process was super easy. In fact, it was so easy, nobody got interviews. We just got hired on 
The pay started off at 15/hr, higher than most places that hired me on so quickly 
Location was 5 minutes from my house
Benefits are good
4 day work week
cons:
NO INTERVIEWS. At first, I thought that was neat. I have never made this much, and it just seemed unbelievable. But then I realized they’re not interviewing anyone at all..so that leads to a literal mystery flavor of what your coworkers will be like 
That 4 day work week sounded extra great in the beginning…never worked 545-515 before. Quickly learned that working practically 12hr days 4 days straight is not where it’s at. 
Hot as hell. The first year I worked there, I was sweating my butt off. When I asked what was going on with the AC, the managers would tell me it was just me, or that the thermostat was based in another city. So even if they did want to lower the temperature, they couldn’t. Why would someone do that…Texas summers are so hot. It was miserable. When winter came along, I had hoped that at least the cool air would help, since all the machines create a lot of heat. Oh no, not only do we have all machines blaring hot air, but we also have the thermostat controlled from a snowy state (I forgot which one)
Management changes very frequently. If you got used to doing one thing a certain way, trash everything you’ve learned. This was one of the main reasons why I left
MET/MTO mandatory OT and mandatory TIME OFF. I was struggling working those 4 12 hour days in the heat, standing/walking on cement..but during peak season, they will give you an entire extra day that you have to be present for. The first year I was there, I was told I couldn’t used my personal time to skip my mandatory days. So I was working 60 hour weeks during the holidays. Then, when business slows down, they had so many people they had hired on as to help during peak season, that they had to MAKE people take time off. Amazon has been the most…unpredictable, illogical job I’ve ever had.

pros: There’s definitely opportunities to level up in this company, once you so critical roles (like waterspider and TDR) you can slowly make your way up to a PA. Made friends, helps the time go by. Holiday pay is great. Money isn’t bad during peak season.
cons: You will have no life with this job. I did 10 hour night shifts. Went to bed at 4 AM, would barely be able to wake up by 2 pm, and then I started work at 4:30 pm again. All I did was eat, sleep, work. After peak season, your pay drops, and the work gets harder since seasonal employees leave. Long hours, my body literally started hurting. They take off a lot of tax, I was making over $1000 per week, but with taxes being taken I barely got $700. There have been times when no trucks were coming (towards the end of the shift) so we literally had to stand for an hour straight doing nothing, they don’t let you sit.. Breaks are really short too, how do you expect me to have my lunch/ dinner in 20 minutes???

pros:
Good pay, but, only if you are an external candidate. If you get promoted within, your pay will be 20 to 30K lower than someone they hire form the outside. Also, they use RSU (Company Stocks) as part of your total compensation package. But you dont get them right away. It takes 3 to 4 years to have all of them vested. And with the volatility of the stock market, well, lets just say my compensation is about 30k lower. Maybe the stocks will go back up, but I would have to stomach this place for a couple more years to reap those benefits. We call them the golden handcuffs. To get the money that is part of your compensation package, you have to stay for a while. 

Good medical benefits.
cons:
Salaried managers are expected to work at least 48 hours a week. Holidays included. 24 hour operation so you may work days or nights. And in some cases, like mine, switch several times. I am on my third shift in 7 months. Very hard to have any sort of normal family life when your schedule is changed every couple of months. 

The only people that seem to get promoted are the scum bags who do not do their job. They are the back stabbers, buddy buddy systems players, work every angle but doing their actual job. The people that actually do their job leave the company for better opportunities, or try to come back after 6 months to be considered an external candidate to make more money.People steal your ideas to use as their own, to pad their "Promotion Document". So, most people tend to not share anything because they are tired of getting their ideas taken by someone else.

The associated are so entitled, that you look at anyone, you will be in front of HR for an investigation. The associates have a manager rating tool, that is not used properly. If they are grumpy, upset, or dont like the fact you actually make them do their job, you get bad ratings. I have seen some employees not even read the questions, just systematically answer the lowest rating on the question to get it over with. 

Reviews are supposed to happen monthly, with a sit down one on one. That hasnt happened in 9 months. The reviews are still posted, and the box is check that the manager sat down with you one on one, but that is a lie.

The company is so inclusive that they are exclusive. There are community groups for Black, Asian, Women, LGBQ, Latinos...etc. But, if you are a straight white hetro male, forget about it. You dont belong. They celebrate those groups and have mandatory classes on them, but now one cares about anyone else.

Inflation is at 9 percent, but the annual raises were 1.5 to 3 percent, depending on tenure.

review_title: Promotion process is what I wouldn't wish even to my enemy
job_title: Software Development Engineer (SDE) II in Vancouver, BC
pros: Working with very intelligent people, there's lots to learn
cons:
Some rigid employee related processes. Extremely difficult and subjective promotion process that requires in some cases politics. 

Compensation wise the company may favor new hires more than seasoned employees with valuable contributions. To move to a different team/role it's not possible to change level, even if the new team strongly thinks you're worth the next level. The only way is to quit, wait (I believe) over 6 months and then interview again. A new hire will get the level but if you're already an employee it's not possible without the formal and very long process of promotion. This applies to changes from engineering to management level, where for example level 5 engineering is not junior but level 5 management is junior. Making such move would cap the compensation lower than currently.

job_title: IT Support Associate II in San Antonio, TX
pros: Learning on the job from day one, you come in expecting to be working on printers and monitors and immediately you are welcomed by the IT team. At my site we have two really good engineers that immediately gave me a tour of the building and broke down the job functions, then two days later on day 3 they asked me to accompany them on a server launch. On day 3 at amazon I was able to see the amazon way of deploying servers and this made me confirm that I made the right choice by leaving my cushy IT job at the school and make a change to a place where i will be challenged daily and learn something new everyday. The pay is also awesome!
cons: I personally am not fond of rotating schedules, as an IT support tech II you are expected to work rotating shifts that go from 7am -530pm or 5pm - 430am, 4 days a week. These shifts rotate on a front end or back end day (Sunday - Wed or Wed - Sunday) So far that is the only downfall to this career.

review_title: Review after 3 months in the company
pros:
- I had a good training experience.
-Very interesting, active and smart people.
- Young team. Everybody very friendly. We do activities together (we even went to ski together. Do not think this is very common everywhere.)
- Working in shift is much better than what I thought before accepting the offer: generally 1 month from 6am to 2pm one month 2from 2pm to 10pm in my case. I have a lot of free time I can spend doing sport, groceries, reading, or whatever.
cons:
-Working from Saturday to Wednesday can be a cons but to me it is not that much because during the month I work in the afternoon shift I can still go out at night and reasonably late.
- Work is rather interesting but after a while repetitive. However, if you want to progress you can spend extra time deep diving with elearning provided by the company in order to understand better the loads of tools you use everyday. This will help make you move forward in your career and array of task you are competent about.

review_title: Tremendous opportunity to drive change and implement your ideas
job_title: Business Systems Analyst II in Arlington, VA
pros: I have personally experienced growth while utilizing Amazon leadership principles on a daily basis. They help you navigate the complexity of this large organization. You will be treated fairly and you will be heard! Once you convince your leaders about an improvement or a new idea you can pretty much run the show and engage in conversations with stakeholders to bring about the change. If this excites you then you will thrive at Amazon.
cons: Your experience may be different if your team is not organized or does not have strong leadership. I have worked with some great people and some who were unable to handle the unstructured work environment that is Amazon.

review_title: Hours are Long, Pay is Painfully Terrible
pros:
I am giving a 3 star purely based on benefits 
Such as medical Aid
Pension 
And the opportunity to study through them after your one year tennure
cons:
The hours are insane, 
the breaks are only to breath from the constant contact handling and abuse from customers.
You could work 4 day shift for 11 hours and it will be the most frustrating and non supportive working place even if you work from home. 
My mental health has seriously decreased ever since I started working. 

Even when you do your best to help the customers, their reviews depend on whether or not they will keep you, 
you have to maintain a good metric at all times and abide by their policy when handling contacts. Dealing with this company's consumers is honestly the most frustrating thing I have ever had to face and you really have to pretend everything is alright and just move on.

review_title: Great if you can get through the start
job_title: Workplace Health and Safety Specialist in Chesapeake, VA
pros: The growth opportunities are insane. Promotions happen quick and internal transfers are abundant if you don't like the field you're in. Very team-focused culture
cons: Mass miscommunications led to a very rough start for me as a college hire. A month into my job with Amazon and I still don't know hardly anything about my day-to-day responsibilities

pros: The Manager (specifically on my team) is absolutely amazing in pushing for me to make a good work life balance, find ways to grow, and help me in my career progression. Compensation from where i came from is really good. Benefits are decent and the company has a lot of family type information that can be used for your benefit. There is always something you can learn at Amazon AWS.
cons: I believe the 401k Match is a little on the low side from what I am used to. There is a lot of information and it can be hard to focus on what you need to be successful.

pros:
Decent supervisors, always make an effort to ask how you are and remember your name.

Benefits are pretty standard.
cons:
Pay is low for high workload, they blow it off because you get an Amazon stock as part of benefits, but don't tell you you have to sign up for it and harrass HR for months before the stock is actually attributed to your account. Selling it for its value is blocked by ridiculous blackout periods and long wait times with the broker.

Not allowed to use restroom outside of breaks, you'll be written up

They track your "Time off Task" by the second and you get in trouble for not working at all times. This doesn't work well when you're a stower and it's off peak.

pros: Building and facilities is good.
cons: Some managers are very strict and stubborn.

job_title: FC Associate I in Flanders, NJ
pros: Understanding friendly management. Flexibility with time off.
cons: Very physical and repetitive at times. Toxic employees are not repremanded quickly/harshly enough.

pros:
- Amazing on-boarding process. They design a three month on-boarding process specialized for each employee starting. They want you to be antonymous. Everyone is responsible for their own on-boarding, but they enable you with the right tools to on-board easily 
- Very supportive team!!! Anyone I have interacted with has been willing to give a helping hand
- Diverse business (e.g., online retail, cloud-computing, advertising)
cons: - For some people I think they would dislike the amount of change that happens. I was personally seeking that when I applied, considering how stagnant my prior job was. I know others on the team struggle with the quantity of change though
